tossups.question: Despite dying of typhoid fever, this man’s cause of death was originally reported by the pro-Federalist Gazette of the United States to be illness of the liver. This man’s only education was received from the Reverend Samuel Dunbar, but he later became a treasurer for Yale College. This man’s son-in-law, Simeon Baldwin, succeeded him in a post of which he was the inaugural holder; that post was Mayor of (*) New Haven, Connecticut. Despite being originally opposed to the idea of replacing the Articles of Confederation, this man would go on to propose the Connecticut Compromise. For 10 points, name this Founding Father, the only man other than Robert Morris to sign the Declaration of Independence, Articles of Confederation, and the U.S. Constitution.

A disputed area in a novel by this man has “corners at Tangier, Brazzaville, Darwin, and Hong Kong.” In another novel by this man, commandments are amended to allow drinking in moderation and beds without sheets, resulting in the maxim that some of the titular characters are “more equal (*) than others.” In that novel, Boxer is purportedly sent to a veterinarian, but is actually sold for slaughter by Napoleon to buy whisky for his inner circle of pigs. In one of this man’s most famous works, crimethink is punished by the thinkpol, or Thought Police, for challenging the rule of Big Brother. For 10 points, name this British author of works like Animal Farm and Nineteen Eighty-Four.

The only known protein containing the unusual amino acid hypusine is the eukaryotic initiation factor 5A for this process. In prokaryotes, deacylated and dipeptidyl versions of a certain protein relocate within an organelle in the cytoplasm in a substep known as translocation, which is catalyzed by elongation factor G. That protein has a (*) cloverleaf structure that allows it to fit into P and A sites. A 5’ [“five prime”] UTR often precedes the sequence AUG that begins this process, which is the start codon for methionine. This process is the last to occur in the central dogma. For 10 points, name this process of initiation, elongation, and termination in which mRNA and tRNA attach to a ribosome to create an amino acid.

The anniversary of this war is celebrated every year on the Feast of the Annunciation. Ibrahim Pasha, the son of Mehmet Ali, was sent to suppress this war; however, he was eventually repelled by the Maniots. A fleet sent to the island of Hydra in this war was intercepted by an allied naval force. This resulted in the Battle of Navarino, which was won by a combined Russian, French, and British fleet. The secret society (*) Filiki Eteria is responsible for inciting this war, which concluded with the signing of the Treaty of Constantinople in 1832. General Theodoros Kolokotronis was the pre-eminent general in, for 10 points, what war, which liberated a European country from Ottoman rule.

When Jesus tells his followers he is going to prepare a place for them in his Father’s house, this man replies, “Lord, we don’t know where you are going, so how can we know the way?” Traditionally, this man is said to have been martyred by being run through with a spear after his 50 C.E. voyage to (*) India. This apostle, whose name means “the twin,” is best known for the circumstances surrounding his profession of the belief in Christ’s resurrection in John 20. For 10 points, name this “doubting” apostle who only believed that Christ rose from the dead after he could put his hands in the wounds in Jesus’ hands and side.

This was originally developed in 1991 with five unique design principles in mind, one of which was that it be “robust and secure.” After the fourth edition, the developers of this decided to switch edition numbering from a decimal number scale to a whole number scale. Developed by James Gosling for Sun Microsystems, the publisher for this platform is now the Oracle (*) Corporation. While the Android operating system is largely written in C, apps for the Android OS are written in this strictly typed computer programming language. For 10 points, name this object-oriented computer programming language, one of the most popular currently in use, which was named for a type of coffee.

The first of these laws were passed by the government of Lord Liverpool in 1815, but was met with great rioting after the increase of bread prices due to the Year Without Summer the next year. Another one of these laws allowed for select Canadian products to enter the United Kingdom without tariff. Benjamin Disraeli was one of the most vocal supporters of these laws, which were repealed by (*) Sir Robert Peel and the opposing Whigs in 1849. David Ricardo opposed these laws, which forgoed free market theory and artificially raised the price of agricultural goods in the United Kingdom. For 10 points, name this controversial set of tariff laws that shares its name with a common crop.

A musical theme that depicts this animal begins with the staccato ascending then descending notes D G B, G D C-sharp. A humorous duet often attributed to Rossini calls for two of these creatures in its title, though it is written for two sopranos who sing only one word. A sonata in G minor by Domenico Scarlatti is a fugue named for this creature, inspired by one called (*) Pulcinella walking across Scarlatti’s keyboard. In Prokofiev’s Peter and the Wolf, this animal is depicted with the clarinet. A musical titled after a tribe of these creatures is based on a work by T. S. Eliot and includes the characters Jennyanydots and Skimbleshanks. For 10 points, name these creatures whose tribe called the Jellicles appears in a musical by Andrew Lloyd Webber.
tossups.answer: cats [prompt on feline or kitty or similar] <McMaken>

tossups.question: Both Bill Belichick, head coach of the New England Patriots, and former Secretary of State Colin Powell were known to take leadership advice from this text. It is divided into 13 sections, one of which is titled “Terrain” in many translations. A 1972 discovery of this text in the family tomb of its writer resolved an authorship dispute among scholars. Officers of the (*) Vietcong could reportedly recite large portions of this text. This text is part of the Marine Corps’ Professional Reading Program and was also used by the KGB for intelligence strategy. For 10 points, name this Chinese text, written in the 5th Century BC by Sun Tzu.

An equation governing this process includes terms like the resistance to mass transfer, the Eddy diffusion, and the longitudinal diffusion, and that equation is often written as HETP equals A plus B over u plus C times u. A wash step in this technique called an elution sees the continuous addition of a (*) mobile phase, whose velocity can be calculated using the van Deemter equation. The Kovats retention index is used in the gas version of this technique, and silica gel draws a solvent up to a plate in the thin-layer version of this technique. For 10 points, name this separation laboratory technique in which a mobile phase moves past a stationary phase, with types like “high-performance liquid,” “column,” and “paper.”

The most recent addition to this book’s series was written by the author of Artemis Fowl, Eoin Colfer. The author of this book notes that his inspiration came while lying drunk in the middle of an Austrian field, clutching a more serious book of a similar title. This novel was adapted from a comical science fiction (*) BBC radio series of the same name, which began airing in 1978. In this book, Earth is demolished by an alien race known as the Vogons to build a bypass for an intergalactic highway. The novel’s protagonist, Arthur Dent, and Ford Prefect go on journey through the universe and encounter a super computer which has calculated the Ultimate Answer to Life, the Universe, and Everything to be 42. For 10 points, name this science fiction novel by Douglas Adams.
tossups.answer: The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy <Stecko>

tossups.question: A British espionage operation in World War II involving copying the contents of diplomatic pouches of neutral countries was named for three instances of this letter in a row. In a 1908 play about a mother with this letter as a last name by Alexandre Bisson, the titular madame is on trial for killing her lover, and this letter is used for (*) Virginie Gautreau’s name in a painting that caused scandal at the Paris Salon in 1884 because of a fallen shoulder strap. A man who gave “The Ballot or the Bullet” speech changed his last name from “Little” to this letter; that man was assassinated in 1965 by members of the Nation of Islam. For 10 points, name this letter which gives the last name for a madame in a John Singer Sargent portrait and the African-American activist Malcolm.

Possibly due to influence from Ovid’s poem Fasti, a figure in this painting was painted with a more blue-green color rather than the traditional peach coloring. The central figure of this painting is wearing a traditional wedding crown. While the subjects are mythological, there are no stories in which all of the figures gather. This led some to believe that the subjects represent (*) various aspects of Renaissance Neoplatonism. A figure on the left of the painting uses a wand to stir clouds, and the blue-green figure grasps a woman with flowers flowing from her mouth. From the top of this painting, Cupid aims an arrow at the three Muses as they dance to the left. For 10 points, name this Botticelli panel painting which depicts the lushness of Spring.
tossups.answer: La Primavera [prompt on The Allegory of Spring] <Yoshida>

tossups.question: In one of this author’s poems, he describes how a certain type of person swears “with an ‘I dew vym,” or an ‘I tell yeou” and concludes with the line “Logic is logic That’s all I say.” This author coined the term “Boston Brahmin,” and his prose works are collected in his Breakfast-Table series. The narrator of another of his poems hears “clearer notes (*)...than ever Triton blew” from the titular “ship of pearl.” In another poem, he advocates to “give her to the god of storms” rather than letting “her shattered bulk” sink, and that poem describes the USS Constitution. For 10 points, name this father of a Supreme Court Justice, the Fireside Poet of “Old Ironsides” and “The Chambered Nautilus.”
tossups.answer: Oliver Wendell Holmes, Sr. [prompt on partial answer] <Kumar>

tossups.question: A priestess in a temple of Athena repeats that “Iodame [eye-AH-du-mee] requires fire,” after this fate befalls Iodame. After Anaxarete [an-aks-uh-REE-tee] spurns the advances of Iphis, this happens to Anaxarete during a festival. This happens to Battus after he is caught stealing the (*) cattle of Hermes, and Zeus first performs this action to resolve a paradox involving Laelaps and the Teumessian Fox. Poseidon inflicts this fate on Odysseus’ ship. This is a punishment of Niobe in addition to crying perpetual tears. This fate befell Atlas when he refused hospitality to Perseus, and an object which causes this was placed on the Aegis of Athena. For 10 points, name this process which occurs when looking upon the head of Medusa.
tossups.answer: petrification [accept turning to stone or other clear equivalents] <Yoshida>

tossups.question: This thing “renounced the two-thirds share of linen of the fine linen that used to be made in the temples for the Treasury.” Examinations of the decree of Canopus show that about a quarter of this is now lost, and the British general John Hely-Hutchinson reluctantly included this in the Capitulation of Alexandria, after which it travelled to its present location in the (*) British Museum. This thing’s name derives from the town of Rashid near Fort Julien, where this item was rediscovered in the Nile Delta. That rediscovery occurred in 1799 while the French soldier Pierre-François Bouchard was on the Napoleonic campaign in Egypt. This artifact’s text centers on King Ptolemy V [“the fifth”]. For 10 points, name this item that allowed for easy comparison between ancient Egyptian hieroglyphics and Demotic and Greek script.

A concept named for Dirac and this thing consists of the region of space outside of a magnetic monopole in which the vector potential is not defined. The QCD type of this is a color-confining degree of freedom that is classified as a noncritical, and in general, that thing with this name is predicted to be about 10-35 meters long and can be (*) “open” or “closed.” Excitations of this type of medium can be seen with a strobe light, and those oscillations travel with a speed equal to the square root of the tension divided by mu, the mass per unit length. For 10 points, name this thing which lends its name to a theory under the eleven-dimensional M-theory as well as a massless, one-dimensional object that can attach to masses on a pulley.

Though not judgment, in the sixth section of a work centered around this term, its author argued that Hume’s analytic view stopped short of considering that this thing could be synthetic through the representation of space itself. Though this term first appeared in Euclid’s Elements, the philosopher who popularized this term used the example of (*) 7 + 5 = 12, since no amount of analysis will find 12 in either 7 or 5. Other examples of this thing include ontological arguments and tautologies like “All bachelors are unmarried.” This type of knowledge appears in Critique of Pure Reason as the epistemological “necessary conclusions from first premises.” For 10 points, name this Latin term popularized by Immanuel Kant that is contrasted with a posteriori.

When discovered by the Dutch, this U.S. river was known as the North River, despite the name only applying to the southernmost portion of this river. The source of this river is Lake Tear of the Clouds, a small lake on the southern face of Mt. Marcy, the highest point of Adirondack High Peaks. The tidal estuary of this river extends as far north as the (*) Federal Dam in Troy and discharges around the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. West Point overlooks this river, prior to entering the city of Yonkers. For 10 points, name this New York river, which flows into the Atlantic Ocean at New York City.

In Act 4 of Il Trovatore, Leonora offers herself in place of her lover Count di Luna in a duet with this name. A work with this title for 120 voices a cappella by Henryk Górecki [gor-ET-ski] was composed in 1981 in protest of the Polish government and was subsequently banned, and a (*) fourteen-year-old Mozart transcribed another piece of this name from memory after hearing it one time at the Sistine Chapel. One famous work of this name from the Renaissance is a Phrygian motet by Josquin [jhaw-SKAN], which includes the line, “secundum magnam misericordiam tuam” [se-COON-dum MAG-nahm mee-zair-i-COR-dee-ahm TOO-ahm]. The text for works of this name derives from the Vulgate’s Psalm 50. For 10 points, give this Latin title of a work by Allegri which translates as “have mercy.”

One deity ruling over this phenomenon was Fornax, and another was slain immediately upon his birth. The Norse giantess governing this phenomenon was Glod, and this phenomenon was also the namesake of the necklace of Freya, (*) Brisingamen. The Hindu god of this phenomenon rode on a ram, and the Chinese one governed the south. Loki once lost an eating contest to the personification of this phenomenon, Logi, and the Phlegethon a river of this substance. Surtr held a sword with this property, and resided in Muspelheim, the world of this phenomenon. For 10 points, name this phenomenon, which Hercules used to prevent the heads of the Lernean Hydra from growing back and which is represented by the gods Hephaestus and Agni.
tossups.answer: fire [accept furnace until the word “slain”] <Yoshida> BONUSES:

bonuses.leadin: Customs officials changed this sculpture collection’s classification from “manufactured metal objects,” to “kitchen utensils and hospital supplies.” For 10 points each:
answer: Bird in Space [do not accept Birds in Space]
parts: Name this sculpture collection made of elongated marble and bronze forms, which sold for a record high of 27.5 million dollars.
Bird in Space is a collection of sculptures by this Romanian sculptor of The Endless Column and The Kiss.
Brancusi also sculpted this bronze statue depicting a sideways head. The model for this statue was Renee Irana Franchon.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about critical events concerning the LGBT community in America, for 10 points each:
parts: This gay bar in Greenwich Village was the home of a namesake June 1969 riot in response to a late-night police raid. Regarded as the start of the gay liberation movement, many pride parades occur on the anniversary of the riots here.

The “Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell” military policy was instituted by this president. The Employment Non-Discrimination Act was first introduced with this president’s support, however, it failed to pass the Senate by one vote.

The Defense of Marriage Act, also instituted by Clinton, was overturned by this 2015 Supreme Court case. The decision of this case requires that all states and territories issue same-sex marriage licenses and to recognize same-sex marriages recognized by other institutions.

bonuses.leadin: The Tu’i Tonga, or king, was the only person in Tongan culture not to have this distinguishing feature, as he was considered too high-ranked to be touched. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this practice, which, in Polynesian tradition, was completed by tapping a sharpened au [OW] dipped in a dye made from soot into ornate designs. The process to receive this distinguishing mark often took many weeks.

Tattoos found on Ötzi, a 5300 year-old man whose remains were preserved in the Tisenjoch Glacier, were the first conclusive evidence of tattooing in this continent. The Picts of this continent were also rumored to have tattoos.

The women of this ethnic group of Japan were tattooed as early as age 12 and had their tattoos completed at age 16. The men of this ethnic group are often recognized by their long beards, as they are forbidden to cut their hair after the age of 16.

bonuses.leadin: The development of quantum theories has a long history. For 10 points each:
parts: Max Planck’s study of radiation from this type of source that ideally reflects no light showed that its modes have to be quantized in order to prevent high frequency intensity from growing to infinity in the so-called ultraviolet catastrophe.

Following the ideas of Planck, Albert Einstein earned a Nobel Prize not for his theories of relativity or mass-energy equivalence, but rather for this effect that showed that light hitting a metal surface could be treated as packets of quanta.

This scientist experimentally verified the photoelectric effect and in the process obtained an accurate value of Planck’s constant. He also obtained a value of the constant for the quantization of electric charge in his namesake oil drop experiment.

bonuses.leadin: This creature burbled and went galumphing back when it died. For 10 points each:
answer: Through the Looking-Glass, and What Alice Found There
parts: Name this creature which titles a nonsense poem by Lewis Carroll that begins, “ ’Twas brillig, and the slithy toves / Did gyre and gimble in the wabe.”
“Jabberwocky” appears in this 1871 sequel of a work chronicling the fantastic journeys of a girl who fell through a rabbit hole.

In “Jabberwocky,” the speaker instructs the reader to “shun / The frumious Bandersnatch” and to “beware” this type of bird, which is described in Carroll’s later poem “The Hunting of the Snark” as “A desperate bird that lives in perpetual passion.”

bonuses.leadin: Alcohol has played a role in history for thousands of years. For 10 points each:
parts: Among the first evidence of wine production was uncovered at Hajji Firuz Tepe in this country. That wine evolved into Ramian wine, which became a delicacy in the Parthian Empire of this modern day country.

In 1516, Wilhelm IV [“the fourth”] implemented Reinheitsgebot [rine-HEIGHTS-guh-BOT], a law in this country requiring that all beers may only have four ingredients. This country still maintains purity laws to this day in spite of legal disputes known as the Brandenburg Wars in the 1990s.
This French Benedictine monk is often miscredited for the invention of champagne in the 17th century. Regardless, he names a high-sought after brand of champagne sold by Moët & Chandon.

bonuses.leadin: This baboon-headed god protected the throne of Osiris in the underworld. For 10 points each:
answer: flooding of the Nile [do not accept or prompt on Nile on its own] <Yoshida>
parts: Name this god who was the protector of the lungs of the deceased.
Hapi and his three brothers were sons of this god. Together, the four brothers were guardians of the canopic jars.
A different Egyptian god also named Hapi governed this phenomenon. There were Egyptian festivals celebrating this “arrival of Hapi.”

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about slave rebellions in the Western Hemisphere, for 10 points each:
parts: History’s most successful slave rebellion was led by this man, who died before Haiti achieved independence in 1804. Having assembled a constitutional assembly in 1801, this man was dubbed Governor-General for Life.

A slave rebellion named after this holiday on the island of Jamaica was led by preacher Samuel Sharpe and mobilized up to 60,000 slaves in 1831. Also known as the Baptist War, this holiday also names an Australian island south of the island of Java.

The Malê Revolt of 1835 in this country was incited by Muslim Yoruba slaves in the city of Salvador. After the revolt, Muslim slaves were forced to convert to Catholicism up until this country’s abolition of slavery in 1888.

bonuses.leadin: These things can be classified by the number of cotyledons in their embryos. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these flowering plants whose name derives from the Greek words for “casing” and “seed,” unlike the similarly-named classification meaning “naked seed.”
The female part of an angiosperm is composed of the stigma, style, and ovary, and is collectively known by this name.
The male part of a flower, the stamen, is composed of a filament attached to this structure, which houses pollen grains that develop from the microspore in the microsporangia of this structure.

bonuses.leadin: In the climax of this work, a struggle over a book inadvertently results in a lamp burning down the book and a library, for 10 points each:
answer: The Name of the Rose [or Il nome della rosa]
Foucault’s Pendulum [or Il pendolo di Foucault] <Luc>
parts: Name this novel that features William of Baskerville and Adso of Melk investigating a series of deaths in an Italian monastery.
The Name of the Rose is by this Italian author of The Prague Cemetery and The Island of the Day Before.
Eco also wrote this satirical novel in which Belbo, Diotallevi, and Casaubon invent and begin to believe in their own conspiracy theory called “The Plan.”

bonuses.leadin: The world’s 2.2 billion Christians are separated into many different denominations. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this mainline Protestant Christian denomination, founded upon the teachings of John Wesley, Charles Wesley, and George Whitefield.
This largest Christian denomination maintains doctrines such as the “true presence” of Christ in the Eucharist, as well as a belief in the primacy of the “Successor of Peter.”
Catholicism and Orthodox Christianity are separated by the Catholic inclusion of the filioque [fil-ee-OH-kway], meaning “and the Son,” in this prayer.

bonuses.leadin: Examples of these things include the figure-eight and the trefoil. For 10 points each:
parts: Give the term for embeddings of circles in three-dimensional Euclidean space. These mathematical objects differ from the conventional notions of their namesakes in that they have no thickness and no ends to untie.
This simplest composite knot is obtained by taking the connected sum of a trefoil knot with its reflection. It is distinct from the granny knot, which is the connected sum of two identical trefoils.

Knot theory categorizes three types of local “moves” named for this mathematician that can be performed on a link diagram without changing the knot itself. These moves consist of a twist, moving a loop over another strand, and moving a loop over a crossing.

bonuses.leadin: Kobayashi Issa was a well-known practitioner of this form, and one work in this form describes the splash of a frog jumping into an ancient pond. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this form of Japanese poetry consisting of 17 morae, or syllables.
The aforementioned frog poem was by this master of haiku who also wrote The Narrow Road to the Deep North. He took his name from a banana tree planted by his house.
Kanshi refers to another form of poetry of Japan that is influenced by and written in this language.

bonuses.leadin: After the 1897 premiere of this man’s first symphony ended in disaster, this composer fell into depression and stopped composing for several years. For 10 points each:
answer: Piano Concerto No. 2 in C minor [prompt on partial answer] <McMaken>
parts: Name this composer and pianist who studied at the Moscow Conservatory and who had hands big enough to reach a 13th.

The premiere of Rachmaninoff’s First Symphony fell under so much criticism in part because of this conductor of the premiere, who incompetent and most likely drunk. This Russian also composed an A-minor Violin Concerto and the ballet The Seasons.

Rachmaninoff eventually decided to seek psychological help with the assistance of the hypnotist Nikolai Dahl, who inspired Rachmaninoff to come out of his depression with the premiere of this piece with Rachmaninoff as the soloist. This piece’s second movement begins with bell-like chords and features a theme used in Eric Carmen’s “All By Myself.”

bonuses.leadin: The F layer of this region is named for Appleton. For 10 points each:
answer: aurora borealis [prompt on partial answer; prompt on northern lights]
parts: Name this region of Earth’s atmosphere, the inner layer of the magnetosphere. It is named for its heavy concentration of charged particles.

During a geomagnetic storm, the Northern polar region will experience this phenomenon in the ionosphere, in which charged particles in solar wind interact with Earth’s magnetic field to form a display of light that for the Southern pole has the modifier “australis.”

The equatorial anomaly in the ionosphere lies at about this many degrees from the Earth’s magnetic equator, within a few degrees. This is also the number of degrees that the Earth is tilted from the plane of its orbit around the Sun.

bonuses.leadin: In a Buddhist parable about this practice, an Abess says that there will be no quibbling about the soup. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this practice of which monks can take a vow, which in Buddhism can accompany meditation if the practitioner chooses not to chant.
In this religion founded by a Persian prophet, dead bodies are left to vultures on “towers of silence” known as dakhmas.
In the namesake rule of this Catholic order, a vow of monastic silence is often considered an essential practice. This order is named for a sixth century saint “of Nursia.”

bonuses.leadin: This poem has no discernible meter, and the title almost flows into the work as though part of a note. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this poem in which the author apologizes to the addressee for eating “the plums / that were in / the icebox” and asks for forgiveness as “they were delicious / so sweet / and so cold.”
“This is Just to Say” is by this American physician and modernist poet who also wrote “The Red Wheelbarrow.”
Williams had corresponded with this other American poet who published both of their works in an anthology, Des Imagistes. This poet also defined Imagist poetry with “In A Station of the Metro.”

bonuses.leadin: This artist was an avid believer in the at-the-time new research of Sigmund Freud. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this surrealist artist who expressed Freudian ideas in works such as Dream Caused by the Flight of a Bee Around a Pomegranate a Second Before Awakening.
The Freudian belief that women were once mysterious but their secrets were now exposed was expressed through these common motifs.
One example of Dali’s Drawer motif was this plaster statue of a woman complete with metal pulls and mink pom-poms.

bonuses.leadin: Diplomatic history is currently in the works. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man, who, amid increased sanctions from the United States, has agreed to meet with President Trump at a time and place yet to be determined. Trump has previously called this North Korean dictator “Rocket Man.”
While a sitting U.S. president has never met with the supreme leader of North Korea, former presidents Jimmy Carter and Bill Clinton did meet with this man, Kim Jong-un’s predecessor and father.
This South Korean Chief National Security Advisor announced Kim’s willingness to meet President Trump.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the Prime Meridian, for 10 points each:
answer: Queen Maud Land [accept Maud Charlotte Mary Victoria] <Halza>
parts: The long time standard for the Prime Meridian has been located in this British town. Despite naming a time zone notated “zero” in Coordinated Universal Time, the meridian in this town is actually 123 meters east of the Prime Meridian’s most recent calculation.
Besides London, this West African city is the closest capital city to the Prime Meridian. Having served as the capital of the British Gold Coast until 1957, this city is the capital of Ghana.

The Prime Meridian also passes through this Antarctic region. Claimed by Norway, this region is named for the wife of King Haakon VII [“the seventh”], who reigned from 1905 to 1957, and who was also the daughter of King Edward VII [“the seventh”] of Great Britain.

bonuses.leadin: While Penelope was virtuously rejecting those who desired her, Odysseus was … well … not. For 10 points each:
answer: eating moly [prompt on eating a plant, if they start blabbering about Hermes still prompt]
parts: On the island of Aeaea, Circe decided that she liked Odysseus when he resisted her spell by doing this.
Later, he spends seven years with Calypso, a resident of this island.
Odysseus misses Penelope and leaves Ogygia, but not before having his way with this Phaeacian princess.
